data_findings.finding: Target distribution: 24.6% success rate (994/4040 received pizza), indicating significant class imbalance favoring negative class
Text features vary significantly: request_title avg 72 chars, request_text avg 405 chars, request_text_edit_aware avg 397 chars. Text length could be predictive.
User flair has 3 values: None (no pizza history), 'shroom' (received pizza), 'PIF' (paid it forward). This is a strong predictive feature.

web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners handle class imbalance in binary classification with 25% positive rate?
web_research.finding:
Kaggle competition winners typically tackle a 25 % positive‑rate binary problem by combining metric‑aware training with data‑level and algorithm‑level tricks — all of which are discussed in Kaggle forums and competition post‑mortems ([Kaggle Q&A](https://www.kaggle.com/questions-and-answers/473546), [Getting‑Started guide](https://www.kaggle.com/getting-started/467908), [Kaggle discussion on imbalance](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/questions-and-answers/27589), [Neptune competition recap](https://neptune.ai/blog/tabular-data-binary-classification-tips-and-tricks-from-5-kaggle-competitions)).

1. **Pick an imbalance‑friendly evaluation metric** – use AUC‑ROC, log‑loss, or F1 rather than plain accuracy, and monitor it during validation ([Kaggle discussion](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/questions-and-answers/27589)).  
2. **Resample the training set** – either oversample the minority class with synthetic techniques such as SMOTE/ADASYN, undersample the majority class, or apply a
